text.__SUMMARY__: Rhododendron dauricum (Chinese: 兴安杜鹃; pinyin: Xīng'ān dùjuān) is a species of flowering plant in the heath family Ericaceae native to forests and forest margins in Eastern Siberia, Mongolia, North China and Hokkaido, Japan. The Latin specific epithet dauricum means “from Siberia”.
text.Description: Growing to 1.5 m (4.9 ft) tall and broad, it is a compact semi-evergreen shrub with purple flowers which open in late winter or early spring, before the dark green leaves appear.
text.Cultivation:
R. dauricum is the basis of the PJM hybrid (Rhododendron dauricum  × Rhododendron carolinianum).
The cultivar ‘Mid-winter’, with bright pink flowers, has gained the Royal Horticultural Society’s Award of Garden Merit. It is hardy down to −20 °C (−4 °F), but like all rhododendrons requires a sheltered position in dappled shade and acid soil enriched with leaf mould.
